head.title: Can the Internet Be Left to the Market?

hedline.hl1: Can the Internet Be Left to the Market?

abstract.p: Cynthia Pansing letter on Karen Kornbluh's Dec 10 article urges government to commit to universal, public access to broadband Internet; drawing

block.p: Karen Kornbluh (''The Broadband Economy,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 10) rightly points to the potential role government can play in correcting the ''last mile'' problem -- connecting homes and businesses to the broadband backbone.

The nationwide fiber-optic network is increasingly seen as a public asset. It is important to ensure that all have equal access to it. Telecommunications companies offer cheaper and faster service where population density is greatest and profits are the highest. Rural areas are increasingly being left behind.

Karen Kornbluh (''The Broadband Economy,'' Op-Ed, Dec. 10) rightly points to the potential role government can play in correcting the ''last mile'' problem -- connecting homes and businesses to the broadband backbone.

The nationwide fiber-optic network is increasingly seen as a public asset. It is important to ensure that all have equal access to it. Telecommunications companies offer cheaper and faster service where population density is greatest and profits are the highest. Rural areas are increasingly being left behind.

Access to telecommunications technology is the gateway to economic development opportunities, education, health care and other essential public services. Our nation runs the risk of widening the digital divide unless the government commits to universal, public access to the broadband network.
The writer is director of the Common Assets Program at Redefining Progress.
